natural problem: What is the sum of all values of $x$ for which $|x-3| + |3-x| -1 = 3$?
natural solution: We will consider two cases. Case 1: $x-3$ is nonnegative. In this case, we have $|x-3| = x-3$. Also, if $x-3$ is nonnegative, then $3-x$ (which is $-1$ times $x-3$) is nonpositive, which means that $|3-x| = -(3-x)$.

So, substituting for the absolute values in the original equation, we have  \[x-3 - (3-x) -1 = 3.\]Solving this equation gives $x = 5$. Case 2: $x-3$ is negative. In this case, we have $|x-3| = -(x-3)$.
Also, when $x-3$ is negative, then $3-x$ is positive, so $|3-x| = 3-x$.
So, substituting for the absolute values in the original equation, we have  \[-(x-3) + 3-x - 1 = 3.\]Solving this equation gives $x = 1$.

Combining our cases, the sum of the values of $x$ that satisfy the equation is $\boxed{6}$. Notice that we could have solved this equation even faster by noticing that $|3-x| = |(-1)(x-3)| = |(-1)||x-3| = |x-3|$, so the original equation simplifies to $2|x-3| - 1 = 3$, which gives us $|x-3| = 2$.
From here, we see that $x$ is 2 away from 3 on the number line, so $x$ is 5 or 1.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (x - 3) + abs (3 - x) - 1 = 3"
shows  "\<Sum>x. abs (x - 3) + abs (3 - x) - 1 = 3 = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all values of $x$ for which $|x-3| + |3-x| -1 = 3$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We will consider two cases. Case 1: $x-3$ is nonnegative. In this case, we have $|x-3| = x-3$. Also, if $x-3$ is nonnegative, then $3-x$ (which is $-1$ times $x-3$) is nonpositive, which means that $|3-x| = -(3-x)$.
 So, substituting for the absolute values in the original equation, we have  \[x-3 - (3-x) -1 = 3.\]Solving this equation gives $x = 5$. Case 2: $x-3$ is negative. In this case, we have $|x-3| = -(x-3)$.
 Also, when $x-3$ is negative, then $3-x$ is positive, so $|3-x| = 3-x$.
 So, substituting for the absolute values in the original equation, we have  \[-(x-3) + 3-x - 1 = 3.\]Solving this equation gives $x = 1$.
 Combining our cases, the sum of the values of $x$ that satisfy the equation is $\boxed{6}$. Notice that we could have solved this equation even faster by noticing that $|3-x| = |(-1)(x-3)| = |(-1)||x-3| = |x-3|$, so the original equation simplifies to $2|x-3| - 1 = 3$, which gives us $|x-3| = 2$.
 From here, we see that $x$ is 2 away from 3 on the number line, so $x$ is 5 or 1.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (x - 3) + abs (3 - x) - 1 = 3"
shows  "\<Sum>x. abs (x - 3) + abs (3 - x) - 1 = 3 = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all values of $x$ such that $|x - 3| + |3 - x| - 1 = 3$. The final answer is 6.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (x - 3) + abs (3 - x) - 1 = 3"
shows  "sum_list (map (\<lambda>x. x) [x]) = 6"

 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs (x - 3) + abs (3 - x) - 1 = 3"
shows  "x = 3 \<or> (\<exists> c. c = 6 - x)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ that satisfies $|x - 3| + |3 - x| - 1 = 3$. The final answer is either $x = 3$ or $x = 6 - c$ for some value $c$.

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "abs(x - 3) + abs(3 - x) - 1 = 3"
shows  "\<forall> x. (\<exists> x. abs(x - 3) + abs(3 - x) - 1 = 3) \<longrightarrow> (\<Sum> x. x) = 6"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
